fullProgramDescription: The Bachelor of Arts in Architecture is an undergraduate degree that provides a comprehensive education in the field of architecture, preparing students for a variety of careers in the field or for further study at the graduate level. The program emphasizes the development of critical thinking, creativity, and technical skills, with a curriculum that includes coursework in architectural history, theory, and design, as well as electives in related fields such as art, engineering, and environmental studies.
shortProgramDescription: The Architecture B.A. program at UC Berkeley provides a broad-based education in the field, preparing students for careers or graduate study through a combination of core and elective coursework.
classHighlights: The program requires students to complete a series of core courses in architectural history and theory, including Architecture 1-2 (Introduction to Architectural History) and Architecture 100A-100B (Architectural Theory and Design).
Students also take coursework in design, including Architecture 101A-101B (Architectural Design Fundamentals) and advanced design studios.

Electives allow students to explore related fields, such as art, engineering, and environmental studies, and to develop their interests in specific areas of architecture, such as sustainability or urban design.
Additional coursework includes Architecture 110 (Introduction to Architecture and Urbanism), Architecture 111 (History of Architecture), and Architecture 112 (Theory of Architecture).
Students can also choose from a range of upper-division electives, including courses in architectural technology, urban planning, and historic preservation.
learningOutcomes: Develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills in the context of architectural design and theory.
Understand the historical and cultural contexts of architecture and urbanism.
Apply technical skills and knowledge in the design and development of architectural projects.
Communicate effectively through written, visual, and oral presentations.
Analyze and evaluate architectural designs and theories.
Demonstrate an understanding of the social, cultural, and environmental implications of architectural practice.
additionalInformation: The program is administered by the Department of Architecture in the College of Environmental Design. Students must meet the university's residency requirement and maintain a minimum GPA. Upper-division transfer students and change-of-major students are also eligible to apply.
